main_text:
Two dimensions of certainty
4. Applications of certainty

Edward Craig (1990) has argued that we can better understand the
concept of knowledge by examining the purpose or purposes it serves.
In a similar way, perhaps, the concept of certainty can be rendered
clearer by looking at the ways in which philosophers have tried to put
certainty to use. Most fundamentally, certainties provide us with
inputs to inference that are stable and secure. If they are immune to
doubt, they can put an end to the demand for reasons that feature in
the Pyrrhonist’s argument for general skepticism (see Sextus
Empiricus, Outlines of Scepticism; Sosa 1997; Sienkiewicz
2019). If they have probability 1, they can simplify reasoning by
allowing the reasoner to treat them as simply given, without having to
attend to the risk of error for each individual premise or the
accumulation of error as uncertain premises are combined. If they are
indefeasible, they can allow us to reject any potential
counterevidence as misleading.

Some philosophers have argued that certainty is the norm of assertion:
one can assert that p just in case one is certain
that p (Stanley 2008; Peterson 2019; Beddor 2020b).
The norm is often defended by adapting Moore’s paradox to certainty
(Moore 1942). According to the original form of the paradox, there is
something infelicitous about assertions like, “It’s raining, but I
don’t believe it is.” Defenders of the certainty norm of assertion
argue that assertions like, “Dogs bark, but I’m not certain that they
do,” are just as odd (Stanley 2008, p. 47). The explanation
of this infelicity is then provided by the fact that
certainty is the norm of assertion. When the speaker asserts, “Dogs
bark,” but then goes on to deny being certain of that claim, she has
undermined her own assertion, contradicting in practice what she has
just said.

Williamson (2000) and Turri (2016) reject the certainty norm of
assertion. Although a certainty version of Moore’s paradox does
sound infelicitous, it doesn’t sound quite so bad as a knowledge
version. Moreover, the oddity of the certainty version can be
explained by the fact that there is generally “a reluctance to allow
the contextually set standards for knowledge and certainty to diverge”
(Williamson 2000, p. 254). That is, the standards for what counts as
knowledge and as certainty typically match one another. Nevertheless,
in some contexts we can pull them apart. When that happens, Williamson
suggests that we assess assertions in accordance with the knowledge
norm. Turri (2016) reports empirical results confirming that this is
in fact the way ordinary speakers assess assertions.

Some philosophers have also argued that certainty is the norm of
practical reasoning: one can rely on p in relevant
practical reasoning just in case one is certain
that p (Beddor 2020a). The argument for the
certainty norm depends on two premises. First, if one is genuinely
relying on the premise that p, one is psychologically
certain that p. If one has a lower credence with respect
to whether p, one is not in fact relying
on p but instead on the proposition that it is
likely that p. Second, the epistemic norm for psychological
certainty is epistemic certainty. To be psychologically certain with
respect to a proposition for which one does not have epistemic
certainty is to violate Hume’s dictum that “A wise man...proportions
his belief to the evidence” (Hume 1748 [2007]).

Although the second premise of the argument seems reasonable enough,
the first premise is overly rigorous. In many cases, the chance of a
premise being false is negligible, though not quite zero.  We
might well rely on it simply because it isn’t worth the effort to
formulate a more precise premise. For example, in choosing a path to
walk home on a day when I am in no particular hurry, I might rely on
the thought that the path I’m on is as good as any other--and I don’t
bother to calculate the possibility that I’m wrong. Even in cases
where I am, in fact, trying to be more careful, I’ll often have to
rely on an uncertain belief at some point. Suppose I’m trying to
decide whether to rely on the proposition
that p but come to see that it is uncertain. So, I
pull back to the claim that it is likely that p. But I
may not be certain that it’s likely that p. If so, I can
either pull back even further--to the proposition that it is likely
that it is likely that p--or I can simply rely, albeit
tentatively, on the proposition that p. In almost every
case, the latter is the more natural course of action to take.

A common objection to both the claim that certainty is the norm of
assertion and the claim that certainty is the norm of practical action
is that certainty is scarce (see Unger 1975). If so, this will mean
that we rarely make proper assertions or behave in a practically
rational way. Defenders of these norms typically respond by offering a
contextualist account of certainty (Stanley 2008, p. 54; Beddor 2020a,
p. 722). On such a view, the epistemic standards governing
attributions of certainty can vary from one context to another.
(Variations in conversational context will yield a contextualist view
of the sort DeRose 1995 defends for knowledge attributions;
variations in practical context will yield a subjective-sensitive or
interest-relative view like those Hawthorne 2004 and Stanley 2005
defend with respect to knowledge.) So, what is certain in one context
may fail to be in another, if the relevant standards have risen in the
latter context. Although some contexts will have relatively stringent
standards for what counts as certain, others may have standards that
are relatively lax. In the latter contexts, then, attaining certainty
shouldn’t be overly challenging.

The debate regarding contextualism is too enormous to enter into here.
Still, it is worth asking whether certainty that is protected by the
contextualist strategy really should count as genuine certainty. After
all, the idea was that a belief one knew with certainty to be correct
was one that made one immune from doubt full stop, and
not just immune from doubt in the present circumstances. It was
supposed to be a belief that one could rely on without hesitation in
drawing inferences, evaluating new evidence, and answering questions
and challenges from others. Contextually protected certainty is
capable of nothing quite so stable and secure. In fact, it looks more
like the epistemic version of moral certainty--good enough for most
purposes, but not as good as it might be (see Matthen 2014
and Locke 2015 for views that more explicitly eschew the label of
“epistemic certainty” in fleshing out this kind of epistemic
status).

Philosophers who defend fallibilism about knowledge will be untroubled
by this outcome (see Hetherington 2001; Reed 2013; Brown 2018). Others
may lament the fading of certainty as an epistemic ideal while arguing
that its abandonment is nevertheless better than going down to
epistemic defeat (Pasnau 2017). A hardy few may continue to press
ahead, like Descartes, in the attempt to “scale the heights of human
knowledge” (PW 1, p. 11; Klein 1981).
